Comment: Jointly with the Committee on Immigration

Items.Title: Jointly with the Committee on Immigration
Oversight - Meeting the Needs of Asylum Seekers in New York City.
Items.MatterName: Oversight - Meeting the Needs of Asylum Seekers in New York City.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to an immigrant workers’ bill of rights
Items.MatterName: An immigrant workers’ bill of rights.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to documentation establishing proof of identity for a New York city identity card
Items.MatterName: Documentation establishing proof of identity for a New York city identity card.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to establishing an office of refugee and migrant settlement
Items.MatterName: Establishing an office of refugee and migrant settlement.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to enhancing the IDNYC application process
Resolution calling on United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to quickly clear the backlog of I-765 applications for employment authorization.
Items.MatterName: United States Citizenship and Immigration Services to quickly clear the backlog of I-765 applications for employment authorization.

Items.Title: Resolution Calling on the United States Congress to pass and the President to sign S. 4529, the “Children’s Safe Welcome Act of 2022,” which would establish standards to ensure the safety and well-being of migrant children in government custody is prioritized, employing best practices in all stages of our immigration system involving unaccompanied and accompanied children who seek asylum in the United States.
Resolution calling on the United States Department of Health and Human Services to prioritize refugee settlement resources to New York City.
Items.MatterName: United States Department of Health and Human Services to prioritize refugee settlement resources to New York City.

Items.Title: Resolution condemning the human trafficking of migrants.
Items.MatterName: Condemning the human trafficking of migrants.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, A.568/S.1802 prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system and prohibiting employers from checking the employment authorization status of an existing employee or an applicant who has not been offered employment.
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting municipalities from requiring all employers to check prospective employees’ work authorization status by using the federal electronic verification system. (A.568/S.1802)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on Governor Hochul to declare an emergency under Section 2-B of New York State Executive Law to direct funds, administrative resources and services to aid asylum seekers forcibly transported to the city by the governors of other states.
Items.MatterName: Governor Hochul to declare an emergency under Section 2-B of NYS Executive Law to direct funds, administrative resources and services to aid asylum seekers forcibly transported to the city by the governors of other states.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign A.170/S.999, also known as the Access to Representation Act, which establishes the right to legal counsel in immigration court proceedings and provides for the administration thereof.

Resolution calling on Congress to pass, and the President to sign, legislation updating the Cuban, Haitian, Nicaraguan, and Venezuelan parole program to allow parolees to work in the United States without waiting for their I-765 applications for employment authorization to be approved, and for the President to take executive action granting or extending temporary access to work permits to asylum seekers currently residing in the United States who are ineligible for the parole program.
Items.MatterName: Updating the Cuban, Haitian, Nicaraguan, and Venezuelan parole program to allow parolees to work in the US without waiting for their I-765 applications for employment authorization to be approved, and for the President to take executive action granting or
